abstract.p: Dr Pepi Granat letter says articles on end-of-life decisions point up need for family physicians who know patients and their families to maintain continuity throughout all their illnesses (S)

block.p: The articles on end-of-life decisions point up the need for family physicians who know patients, their families, their wishes, and who maintain continuity throughout all their illnesses (May 29 and 30).

Despite advances in training specialists in family medicine and internal medicine (which definitely includes death and dying), the H.M.O. system, Medicare and patients themselves -- while claiming to value these physicians -- have used them for triage, discouraging their participation in concurrent care. Patients are handed off to subspecialists who, though competent, have scant sense of the patients' longitudinal history.

The articles on end-of-life decisions point up the need for family physicians who know patients, their families, their wishes, and who maintain continuity throughout all their illnesses (May 29 and 30).

Despite advances in training specialists in family medicine and internal medicine (which definitely includes death and dying), the H.M.O. system, Medicare and patients themselves -- while claiming to value these physicians -- have used them for triage, discouraging their participation in concurrent care. Patients are handed off to subspecialists who, though competent, have scant sense of the patients' longitudinal history.

Perhaps it will take increasing pain on the part of families to restore the demand for the family physician to assume a crucial role in the medical supervision of all patients, especially at life's end.
DR. PEPI GRANAT South Miami, Fla.
